Suddenly, someone is there at the turnstile

A turnstile is a form of gate that limits entry into a certain area and can be used in a range of applications from security to crowd control. Turnstiles evolved from the stile that was used for separating plots of land on farms and keeping animals in specific areas. The first use of turnstiles in a public place was at the Hampden Park stadium in Glasgow.

In the case of Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds, it is possible the turnstile could symbolize the end or continuation of the listeners journey with Lucy. Because a turnstile separates areas but still allows passage it leaves it up to the listener to determine the ending.

Look for the girl with the sun in her eyes
 And she’s gone

Interestingly, St. Lucy was the patron saint of blindness. According to legend, she had her eyes gouged out. When she was being prepared for burial, her eyes were miraculously restored.



The protagonist “Lucy,” however, seems to appear and disappear—perhaps reminiscent of recurring hallucinations caused by LSD.

Lucy in the sky with diamonds
 Ahh

“I showed up at John’s house and he had a drawing Julian had done at school with the title ‘Lucy In The Sky With Diamonds’ above it. Then we went up to his music room and wrote the song, swapping psychedelic suggestions as we went. I remember coming up with ‘cellophane flowers’ and ‘newspaper taxis’ and John answered with things like ‘kaleidoscope eyes’ and ‘looking glass ties’. We never noticed the LSD initial until it was pointed out later – by which point people didn’t believe us.”
-Paul McCartney, Beatles Bible

“It was purely unconscious that it came out to be LSD. Until somebody pointed it out, I never even thought of it. I mean, who would ever bother to look at initials of a title? It’s not an acid song. The imagery was Alice in the boat. And also the image of this female who would come and save me – this secret love that was going to come one day. So it turned out to be Yoko, though, and I hadn’t met Yoko then. But she was my imaginary girl that we all have.
–John Lennon (All We Are Saying, by David Sheff)

In 1968, John Fred and His Playboy Band had a number 1 hit with “Judy in Disguise (With Glasses)”—a parody on LSD with lines like:

Lemonade pies with your brand new car
Cantaloupe eyes come to me tonight
Judy in disguise, with glasses
With plasticine porters with looking glass ties

Plasticine is a brand of modeling clay most commonly used in stop-motion animation films. A porter is a rail worker employed to assist passengers aboard a train or to handle their baggage.

The “looking glass ties” are a direct reference to Lewis Carrol’s 1871 novel, Through the Looking Glass, the sequel to 1865’s Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.



All four Beatles, and John Lennon in particular, were influenced by Carrol’s work. References to his stories and characters can be found throughout their catalog.

Lucy in the sky with diamonds

So it turned out to be Yoko, though, and I hadn’t met Yoko then. But she was my imaginary girl that we all have.”
- John Lennon, All We Are Saying by David Sheff.

In 1968, American John Fred and the Playboys had a number 1 hit with “Judy in Disguise”, a parody on LSD with lines like –

Lemonade pies with your brand new car
Cantaloupe eyes come to me tonight
Judy in disguise, with glasses

Climb in the back with your head in the clouds
 And you’re gone

To have your “head in the clouds” means to be blissfully unaware of what is going on due to fantasies or daydreams.

The closing lines to verse two are reminiscent of the opening lines from “Tomorrow Never Know,” the final track on Revolver, released in 1966:

Turn off your mind, relax and float downstream
It is not dying, it is not dying

Somebody calls you, you answer quite slowly
 A girl with kaleidoscope eyes

A kaleidoscope is a cylinder with mirrors containing loose, colored objects such as beads or pebbles and bits of glass. As the viewer looks into one end, light entering the other end creates a colorful pattern, due to the reflection off the mirrors.

John Lennon uses this imagery to describe Lucy’s beautiful features.



Interestingly, St. Lucy was the patron saint of blindness. According to legend, she had her eyes gouged out. When she was being prepared for burial, her eyes were miraculously restored.

Lucy in the sky with diamonds

So it turned out to be Yoko, though, and I hadn’t met Yoko then. But she was my imaginary girl that we all have.“
- John Lennon, All We Are Saying by David Sheff.

In 1968, American John Fred and the Playboys had a number 1 hit with “Judy in Disguise”, a parody on LSD with lines like –

Lemonade pies with your brand new car
Cantaloupe eyes come to me tonight
Judy in disguise, with glasses

Everyone smiles as you drift past the flowers
 That grow so incredibly high
This is more “Alice In Wonderland” inspired imagery.
The girl with kaleidoscope eyes

This could easily have two different meanings:


The first could relate to the mirror part of a kaleidoscope and how the perfect girl reflects you in some way, and this is why you like her so much.
The imagery certainly sounds reminiscent of LSD. Despite that John himself stated that the song was not explicitly written about an acid trip, lyrics like this one could, either consciously or subconsciously, have been inspired by those experiences, however.
